verses.text: Vindicate me, O LORD, for I have walked in my integrity, and I have trusted in the LORD without wavering.
verses.comment: David asks for God's judgment based on his integrity. This anticipates Jesus' blameless walk and ultimate vindication (Heb. 4:15). It subtly points to the importance of grace and divine help, rather than self-righteousness—echoed in Catholic understanding of sanctification.

verses.text: Examine me, O LORD, and test me; try my heart and my mind.
verses.comment: God examines both heart and mind—a reminder that faith includes interior conversion, a key theme in Catholic spirituality. See also Matt. 5:8.

verses.text: For your steadfast love is before my eyes, and I walk in your faithfulness.
verses.comment: The Psalmist relies on God's covenant love ('chesed'), foundational for the Church's understanding of enduring grace—continuing in both Old and New Covenants (Matt. 26:28).

verses.text: I do not sit with men of falsehood, nor do I associate with hypocrites.
verses.comment: Separation from sin and hypocrisy resonates with Christ's call to holiness (Matt. 23:27). The Catholic tradition of the communion of saints draws us into authentic community.

verses.text: I hate the assembly of evildoers, and I will not sit with the wicked.
verses.comment: Rejecting the 'assembly' of the wicked contrasts with the assembly of the righteous, prefiguring the Church as the true gathering of God's people (Heb. 12:22-23).

verses.text: I wash my hands in innocence and go around your altar, O LORD,
verses.comment: Washing hands suggests ritual purity, pointing to the importance of sacramental cleansing (like baptism) in approaching God—a practice retained in the Catholic liturgy. Compare symbolism to Pilate in Matt. 27:24.

verses.text: proclaiming aloud a song of thanksgiving, and telling all your wondrous deeds.
verses.comment: Public thanksgiving mirrors the Church's ongoing worship (Eucharist means 'thanksgiving'), subtly alluding to the Mass as spiritual sacrifice (1 Cor. 11:24).

verses.text: O LORD, I love the habitation of your house, the place where your glory dwells.
verses.comment: The Psalmist's love for God's house anticipates Christian longing for the Church as God's dwelling. For Catholics, God's real presence endures in the Eucharist—fulfilling Old Testament hopes (John 1:14).

verses.text: Do not sweep away my soul with sinners, nor my life with men of bloodshed,
verses.comment: David pleads for deliverance at judgment, echoing final separation of righteous and wicked (Matt. 25:32-33). This points to the Catholic doctrine of particular and final judgment.

verses.text: in whose hands are evil deeds, and whose right hands are full of bribes.
verses.comment: Condemnation of bribes reinforces God's justice and the call to detachment from material gain—a virtue central to Catholic social teaching.

verses.text: But as for me, I walk in my integrity; redeem me and be gracious to me.
verses.comment: 'Redeem me' foreshadows Christ the Redeemer. Catholic tradition sees David’s prayer answered fully in Christ, whose grace is mediated through His Church (Eph. 1:7).

verses.text: My foot stands on level ground; in the great assembly I will bless the LORD.
verses.comment: Worship in the 'great assembly' foreshadows communal liturgical worship. For Catholics, this Psalm points to the unity and the visible assembly of the Church, as prefigured in Israel's worship and fulfilled in the mystical body of Christ.
